results.name: Number of lattice points (x,y) on the circumference of a circle of radius n with center at (0,0).
comment: Also number of Gaussian integers x + yi having absolute value n. - _Alonso del Arte_, Feb 11 2012
link: Reinhard Zumkeller, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..1000
Michael Gilleland, Some Self-Similar Integer Sequences
Eric Weisstein's World of Mathematics, Circle Lattice Points
formula: a(n) = 4 * Product_{i=1..k} (2*e_i + 1) for n > 0, given that p_i^e_i is the i-th factor of n with p_i = 1 mod 4. - _Orson R. L. Peters_, Jan 31 2017
a(n) = [x^(n^2)] theta_3(x)^2, where theta_3() is the Jacobi theta function. - _Ilya Gutkovskiy_, Apr 20 2018
example: a(5) = 12 because the circumference of the circle with radius 5 will pass through the twelve points (5, 0), (4, 3), (3, 4), (0, 5), (-3, 4), (-4, 3), (-5, 0), (-4, -3), (-3, -4), (0, -5), (3, -4) and (4, -3). Alternatively, we can say the twelve Gaussian integers 5, 4 + 3i, ... , 4 - 3i all have absolute value of 5.

mathematica: Table[Length[Select[Flatten[Table[r + I i, {r, -n, n}, {i, -n, n}]], Abs[#] == n &]], {n, 0, 49}] (* _Alonso del Arte_, Feb 11 2012 *)
program: (PARI) a(n)=if(n==0, return(1)); my(f=factor(n)); 4*prod(i=1,#f~, if(f[i,1]%4==1, 2*f[i,2]+1, 1)) \\ _Charles R Greathouse IV_, Feb 01 2017
(PARI) a(n)=if(n==0, return(1)); t=0; for(x=1, n-1, y=n^2-x^2; if(issquare(y), t++)); return(4*t+4) \\ _Arkadiusz Wesolowski_, Nov 14 2017
